summary: This document is an email chain between US Attorney's Office personnel and a contractor (PAE) discussing delays in processing and producing evidence (images and documents) related to the Epstein case. The emails focus on logistical issues with bates stamping, de-duplication, and meeting a November 9, 2020 production deadline.

persons.name: Nicholas D. Koontz
persons.context: He is the contractor from PAE providing an update on the status of evidence production, detailing what is being sent and the timeline for imaging approximately 1.2 million records.

events.title: Evidence Production Deadline
events.description: A deadline by which evidence (including 40,000 images and documents from FBI Florida boxes and FOIA office) needed to be produced in the Epstein case.

events.title: Prior Request for Image Processing
events.description: A reference to a point prior to October 21-22, 2020, when a request was made to 'burn' (likely process/copy) 40,000 images.

events.title: Earliest Image Availability
events.description: The date when approximately 1.2 million records being imaged would become available in the workspace, after which production could begin.

locations: FBI Florida boxes (implied location of evidence origin)
keyFacts: There were significant delays in processing evidence for the Epstein case, with over 40,000 images and documents from FBI sources awaiting production as of late October 2020.
A contractor (PAE) had de-duplicated images without prior authorization, causing a rework and contributing to the delay.
Approximately 1.2 million records were still being imaged, with availability not expected until at least November 2, 2020, making the November 9 production deadline unlikely to be fully met.
The email chain involves personnel from the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS), but their names are redacted.
